'''Arthur "Big Boy" Spires''' (February 25, 1912 - October 22, 1990) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[singer]] and [[guitar]]ist, who recorded for a number of [[record label]]s in Chicago in the 1950s and 1960s.

==Life and career==
Spires was born in [[Natchez, Mississippi]] (some sources give his birthplace as [[Yazoo City, Mississippi|Yazoo City]]) on February 25, 1912.<ref name="Chess">{{cite web|url=http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/chess1.html|title=The Chess Label Part I|publisher=hubcap.clemson.edu|accessdate=2010-05-09}}</ref>  Although he didn't take up the guitar until the late 1930s, he was proficient enough by 1939 or 1940 to work with [[Lightnin' Hopkins]] at the Beer Garden in Yazoo City.<ref name="Rowe128">Rowe 1981 p.128</ref>

In 1943 Spires moved to Chicago, and started playing for house parties, graduating to playing clubs by the early 1950s.  Spires was a limited guitarist,<ref name="Rowe128"/> and during this time he recruited the young guitarists Louis and David Myers, who later went on to form [[The Aces (blues band)|The Aces]], as part of his backing band.<ref name="Allmusic">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p192708/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=allmusic ((( Arthur "Big Boy" Spires > Biography )))|publisher=www.allmusic.com|accessdate=2010-05-09}}</ref>

By the time of his first recording session for [[Chess Records|Chess]] in 1952 Spires was working with a band called the Rocket Four, including Eddie El on guitar and [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]] on drums<ref name="Chess"/> or harmonica.<ref name="Rowe129">Rowe 1981, p.129</ref>  The recording session, however, featured a three guitar line-up with Spires, El, and Earl Dranes, supplemented by Smith on [[maracas]] on one of the two tracks, "Murmer Low".<ref name="Chess"/>  While sales of the resulting single were poor, both sides, especially "Murmer Low" which has a strong [[Tommy Johnson (blues musician)|Tommy Johnson]] influence,<ref name="Rowe128"/> are today regarded as classics of the Chicago blues genre.<ref name="Chess"/><ref name="Rowe113">Rowe 1981, p.113</ref>

A second recording session for [[Chance Records|Chance]] in 1953 resulted in another single being released, although a further four sides by Spires and two by guitarist [[Johnny Williams (blues musician)|Johnny Williams]] remained unissued until the 1970s.<ref name="Chance">{{cite web|url=http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/chance.html|title=The Chance Label|publisher=hubcap.clemson.edu|accessdate=2010-05-09| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20100428114327/http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/chance.html| archivedate= 28 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>  A further recording session in December 1954 produced four sides, but although the tapes went to [[United Records]] these were not released until 1989, possibly because of sound quality issues.<ref name="Al Smith">{{cite web|url=http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/alsmith1.html|title=The Al Smith Discography part 1|publisher=hubcap.clemson.edu|accessdate=2010-05-09| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20100429190440/http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/alsmith1.html| archivedate= 29 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

Spires continued to perform with the Rocket Four through the 1950s, and recorded another largely unissued session for the [[Testament Records (USA)|Testament]] label in 1965, but was forced to give up the guitar as a result of [[arthritis]].  He died in Chicago on October 22, 1990.<ref name="Chess"/>
